message.raw:
Whitelist tensorflow in double import denier.

Tensorflow contains true double imports. Bug reported here:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/35369

But let's work around it in the meantime.

message.raw:
Automatically updated pinned apps when running fix_shortcuts()

Make fix_shortcuts() more cautious in deleting shortcuts, only deleting
a shortcut from the labscript suite install directory if it has a matching
entry in the start menu and has the name of one of the apps in it.

This makes it safer for code to call fix_shortcuts() automatically.

Automatically updated pinned apps when running fix_shortcuts()

entry in the start menu and has the name of one of the apps in it.

This makes it safer for code to call fix_shortcuts() automatically.

message.raw:
Rename `labscript_suite_install_dir` to `labscript_suite_profile` (keeping the
old name as an alias for backward compatibility), since in the
upcoming restructuring, this will not be where the applications and libraries
are installed to, it will instead be the user's code, config and save data, and
app launchers, which we're calling a 'profile'.

Modify winshell functions to use the import path of each app instead of assuming
their locations within the profile directory (since they will not longer be
there in future).

Modify `versions._get_import_path()` to detect whether a package within the
`labscript_suite_profile` directory is a restructured repository with a
`setup.py`. If it is, then return the repository as the import
path, rather than the `labscript_suite_profile` directory.

This combined with 'shim' `__init__.py` and `__main__.py` files in restructured
packages to redirect imports and running `__main__.py` to the package one
directory down will allow these repositories to continue functioning as
previously even after they are restructured.

Minor version bump so that restructured packages can depend on the changed
functionality.

old name as an alias for backward compatibility), since in the
upcoming restructuring, this will not be where the applications and libraries
are installed to, it will instead be the user's code, config and save data, and
app launchers, which we're calling a 'profile'.

Modify winshell functions to use the import path of each app instead of assuming
their locations within the profile directory (since they will not longer be
there in future).

Modify versions._get_import_path() to detect whether a package within the
labscript_suite_profile directory is a restructured repository with a
setup.py. If it is, then return the repository as the import
path, rather than the labscript_suite_profile directory.

This combined with 'shim' __init__.py and __main__.py files in restructured
packages to redirect imports and running __main__.py to the package one
directory down will allow these repositories to continue functioning as
previously even after they are restructured.

Minor version bump so that restructured packages can depend on the changed
functionality.

Rename labscript_suite_install_dir to labscript_suite_profile (keeping the
old name as an alias for backward compatibility), since in the
upcoming restructuring, this will not be where the applications and libraries
are installed to, it will instead be the user's code, config and save data, and

values.message:
Rename `labscript_suite_install_dir` to `labscript_suite_profile` (keeping the
old name as an alias for backward compatibility), since in the
upcoming restructuring, this will not be where the applications and libraries
are installed to, it will instead be the user's code, config and save data, and
app launchers, which we're calling a 'profile'.

Modify winshell functions to use the import path of each app instead of assuming
their locations within the profile directory (since they will not longer be
there in future).

Modify `versions._get_import_path()` to detect whether a package within the
`labscript_suite_profile` directory is a restructured repository with a
`setup.py`. If it is, then return the repository as the import
path, rather than the `labscript_suite_profile` directory.

This combined with 'shim' `__init__.py` and `__main__.py` files in restructured
packages to redirect imports and running `__main__.py` to the package one
directory down will allow these repositories to continue functioning as
previously even after they are restructured.

Minor version bump so that restructured packages can depend on the changed
functionality.

message.raw:
Log to <labscript_suite>/logs instead of individual program directories

This will assist the move to regular Python packages, where it doesn't make a
lot of sense to log to python/lib/site-packages.

Tell zprocess servers to log to the same directory, and require the version
of zprocess that introduces that option.

of zprocess that introduces that option.

message.raw:
Prevent race conditions in filewatcher stopping - modified info after
shutdown is now guaranteeed to reflect file changes before stop() was called.

Introduce "clean modified info" that can be returned by a method, which
is not just what the user passed in, but also the initial info for files
that the user did not pass in a value for.

BLACS saving just the modified info made no sense. It needs to save the clean
modified into against which changes will be detected.

Compare file list and not just modificiation in order to determine whether
everything is in the initial state.

Only remove deleted files from the list of files to watch if they were not files
that were explicitly added (i.e. they are files within a tracked directory,
created after the watch behan). This  way, a deletion and restoration of a
watched file can trigger a 'original' event.

values.message:
Prevent race conditions in filewatcher stopping - modified info after
shutdown is now guaranteeed to reflect file changes before stop() was called.

Introduce "clean modified info" that can be returned by a method, which
is not just what the user passed in, but also the initial info for files
that the user did not pass in a value for.

BLACS saving just the modified info made no sense. It needs to save the clean
modified into against which changes will be detected.

Only remove deleted files from the list of files to watch if they were not files
that were explicitly added (i.e. they are files within a tracked directory,
created after the watch behan). This  way, a deletion and restoration of a
watched file can trigger a 'original' event.

message.raw:
Remove unnecessary blockiter stuff, md5 hasher does this automatically.
Downside is we read the whole file into memory - I don't think this
is an issue, we're not going to be hashing files big enough to fill our memory
(and we read these files into memory all at once in every other context)
message.html:
Remove unnecessary blockiter stuff, md5 hasher does this automatically.
Downside is we read the whole file into memory - I don't think this
is an issue, we're not going to be hashing files big enough to fill our memory
(and we read these files into memory all at once in every other context)

message.raw:
* Ignore case of hashable types.
* Implicit recursion into subdirectories of specified folders is now optional.
* More extensive code comments.
* Create test file and folder in __main__ if not existent.

• Ignore case of hashable types.
  • Implicit recursion into subdirectories of specified folders is now optional.
  • More extensive code comments.
  • Create test file and folder in main if not existent.

values.message:
* Ignore case of hashable types.
* Implicit recursion into subdirectories of specified folders is now optional.
* More extensive code comments.
* Create test file and folder in __main__ if not existent.

message.raw:
* docstring to FileWatcher.__init__
* polling interval and hashable_types are now keyword arguments.
* Use inspect.getfullargspec for Python 3 (getargspec is deprecated).
* Catch IOError in addition to OSError when file is deleted or unavailable.
* Track first execution of FileWatcher.check so that modified_info_original can be initialised.
* Detect restoration of all originally watched files.

  • Catch IOError in addition to OSError when file is deleted or unavailable.
  • Track first execution of FileWatcher.check so that modified_info_original can be initialised.
  • Detect restoration of all originally watched files.

values.message:
* docstring to FileWatcher.__init__
* polling interval and hashable_types are now keyword arguments.
* Use inspect.getfullargspec for Python 3 (getargspec is deprecated).
* Catch IOError in addition to OSError when file is deleted or unavailable.
* Track first execution of FileWatcher.check so that modified_info_original can be initialised.
* Detect restoration of all originally watched files.

message.raw:
Watch files of a specified type (.py, .ini, .txt) using MD5 hash, so that file
restoration can be detected. callback function can take a third argument, to
discriminate file modified, restored, or deleted events.

message.raw:
Compatibility with importlib_metadata >= 0.21

importlib_metadata's interface changed in this version in a way that broke
our functions. They have now been updated to work with newer versions of
importlib_metadata, whilst remaining compatible with older versions for now
(at the very least we need to keep compatibility until new importlib_metadata is
in the anaconda repositories).

in the anaconda repositories).

message.raw:
Fix the bug that motivated the better error message.

Using the better error message, the bug was located and fixed.
The problem was that as of the serialised_attributes changes, the
labscript_utils.properties module imported h5py but not h5_lock, and so code
that imported labscript_utils.properties prior to h5_lock would cause the error
to be raised.

Rather than have labscript_utils.properties import h5_lock, it now lazy-imports
h5py within the functions that need it, so that the import order no longer
matters.

h5py within the functions that need it, so that the import order no longer
matters.

Fix the bug that motivated the better error message.

Using the better error message, the bug was located and fixed.
The problem was that as of the serialised_attributes changes, the
labscript_utils.properties module imported h5py but not h5_lock, and so code
that imported labscript_utils.properties prior to h5_lock would cause the error
to be raised.

Rather than have labscript_utils.properties import h5_lock, it now lazy-imports
h5py within the functions that need it, so that the import order no longer
matters.

message.raw:
Bugfix for double_import_denier and better error message for h5_lock

* Double import denier had a bug where a module that was already imported
  when double import denier was enabled would be stored in its list of modules
  by its `__file__` attribute. However, the import machinery as used later
  by double import denier actually identifies modules by their directory for the
  case of an `__init__.py` file. Therefore to match with later checks, this
  directory should be stored instead when the module's file is `__init__.py`.

* h5_lock must be imported before h5py, and raises an error if h5py is already
  imported. This commit improves the error message by using the double import
  denier, if enabled, to show the traceback it saved from when h5py was imported.

The motivation for this is a bug I've heard about from two people that they're
getting an error from h5_lock saying h5py was already imported, and I don't know
where. There are hacks you can do to diagnose this locally, but making the error
message better will allow us to handle such bugs easier in the future.

Longer term we should probably stop monkey-patching h5py and instead just use
a subclass, but that's a change for another day.
message.html:
Bugfix for double_import_denier and better error message for h5_lock

  • Double import denier had a bug where a module that was already imported
    when double import denier was enabled would be stored in its list of modules
    by its __file__ attribute. However, the import machinery as used later
    by double import denier actually identifies modules by their directory for the
    case of an __init__.py file. Therefore to match with later checks, this
    directory should be stored instead when the module's file is __init__.py.

  • h5_lock must be imported before h5py, and raises an error if h5py is already
    imported. This commit improves the error message by using the double import
    denier, if enabled, to show the traceback it saved from when h5py was imported.

The motivation for this is a bug I've heard about from two people that they're
getting an error from h5_lock saying h5py was already imported, and I don't know
where. There are hacks you can do to diagnose this locally, but making the error
message better will allow us to handle such bugs easier in the future.

Longer term we should probably stop monkey-patching h5py and instead just use
a subclass, but that's a change for another day.

values.message:
Bugfix for double_import_denier and better error message for h5_lock

* Double import denier had a bug where a module that was already imported
  when double import denier was enabled would be stored in its list of modules
  by its `__file__` attribute. However, the import machinery as used later
  by double import denier actually identifies modules by their directory for the
  case of an `__init__.py` file. Therefore to match with later checks, this
  directory should be stored instead when the module's file is `__init__.py`.

* h5_lock must be imported before h5py, and raises an error if h5py is already
  imported. This commit improves the error message by using the double import
  denier, if enabled, to show the traceback it saved from when h5py was imported.

The motivation for this is a bug I've heard about from two people that they're
getting an error from h5_lock saying h5py was already imported, and I don't know
where. There are hacks you can do to diagnose this locally, but making the error
message better will allow us to handle such bugs easier in the future.

Longer term we should probably stop monkey-patching h5py and instead just use
a subclass, but that's a change for another day.

message.raw:
Lazy import importlib_metadata so that errors about it can be deferred until
after labscript_utils.excepthook has been set up by applications.
Otherwise exceptions can be silent.

after labscript_utils.excepthook has been set up by applications.
Otherwise exceptions can be silent.

message.raw:
Do not use importlib_metadata to inspect its own version initially,
this is circular logic. Just trust importlib_metadata.__version__, then
follow up with a full check only if that is high enough.
message.html:
Do not use importlib_metadata to inspect its own version initially,
this is circular logic. Just trust importlib_metadata.version, then
follow up with a full check only if that is high enough.

message.raw:
Add two new functions get_attributes and set_attributes, for getting and setting
attributes with the automatic JSON serialisation/deserialisation on arbitrary
HDF5 groups, not just device groups. This is basically just exposing the same
functionality as the get/set device properties functions, but allowing you
to specify the HDF5 group instead of the device name.

This can be used by BLACS workers and by the lyse API to enable saving
acquisition metadata and analysis results that are more complex datatypes.

This is motivated by [labscript devices pull request #71](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_devices/pull-requests/71)
which is a camera device that would like to save nested dictionaries as
attributes.

Minor version bump so other code can rely on this.

message.raw:
Fix extremely subtle bug where waiting on other threads in any way
in h5py.File.close() could deadlock Python. This was observed making
runmanager hang periodically.
message.html:
Fix extremely subtle bug where waiting on other threads in any way
in h5py.File.close() could deadlock Python. This was observed making
runmanager hang periodically.

values.message:
Fix extremely subtle bug where waiting on other threads in any way
in h5py.File.close() could deadlock Python. This was observed making
runmanager hang periodically.

message.raw:
Since signal handler connection must be in the main thread, instantiate
the kill lock at import of ls_zprocess rather than within the opening
of the HDF5 file, which could be in any thread.
message.html:
Since signal handler connection must be in the main thread, instantiate
the kill lock at import of ls_zprocess rather than within the opening
of the HDF5 file, which could be in any thread.

the kill lock at import of ls_zprocess rather than within the opening
of the HDF5 file, which could be in any thread.

the kill lock at import of ls_zprocess rather than within the opening
of the HDF5 file, which could be in any thread.

values.message:
Since signal handler connection must be in the main thread, instantiate
the kill lock at import of ls_zprocess rather than within the opening
of the HDF5 file, which could be in any thread.

message.raw:
Have processes delay terminating until after they have closed HDF5 files.
This can prevent data corruption and ensure zlocks are released when
the process is terminated.

This may not play well with any processes that hold the HDF5 file open for
long periods of times, but such processes should be changed to be more polite.
message.html:
Have processes delay terminating until after they have closed HDF5 files.
This can prevent data corruption and ensure zlocks are released when
the process is terminated.

This may not play well with any processes that hold the HDF5 file open for
long periods of times, but such processes should be changed to be more polite.

message.raw:
Acquire import lock when checking modules as well as unloading them.
Add all modules we are not interested in to the whitelist so that we
don't check things like whether they exist on disk again and again after the
first time.

Fix bug where module objects were added to the whitelist instead of their name.

first time.

Fix bug where module objects were added to the whitelist instead of their name.
